message_1: A student is trying to partition the number 7 into non-negative integers using at most three parts. How many ways are there to do this?
message_2:
To partition the number 7 into non-negative integers using at most three parts, we can consider the following cases:

1. Using one part: There is only one way to do this, which is 7 itself (7 = 7).

2. Using two parts: We can have the following combinations:
   - 6 + 1 = 7
   - 5 + 2 = 7
   - 4 + 3 = 7
   There are 3 ways in this case.

3. Using three parts: We can have the following combinations:
   - 5 + 1 + 1 = 7
   - 4 + 2 + 1 = 7
   - 4 + 1 + 2 = 7 (order matters in this case)
   - 3 + 3 + 1 = 7
   - 3 + 2 + 2 = 7
   - 3 + 1 + 3 = 7 (order matters in this case)
   - 2 + 2 + 3 = 7 (order matters in this case)
   There are 7 ways in this case.

In total, there are 1 (one-part) + 3 (two-parts) + 7 (three-parts) = 11 ways to partition the number 7 into non-negative integers using at most three parts.
